FacilityName: Omaha Public Power Nebraska City Power Station

_prev_prog_3.Description:
OPPD's Program 3 Prevention Program for the anhydrous ammonia system is a rigorous program which meets the requirements of both the RMP and the PSM regulations. 



OPPD updated and revalidated its Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) on 12/28/2012. The review examined the hazards associated with the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) process and the use of anhydrous ammonia. It also assessed the opportunities for equipment malfunction or human errors that could cause an accidental release. Safeguards used or needed to control the hazards or prevent equipment malfunction or human error were evaluated. The analysis also included the review of steps used or needed to detect or monitor releases. 



In addition to the PHA, OPPD's Program 3 Prevention Program incorporates all of the required elements, including:



Operating Procedures: OPPD has developed written operating procedures for the safe storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia at Nebraska City Station. The procedures specify steps for each operating phase of the process and operating limits (e.g., pressure in the tanks). OPPD has outlined appropriate safety and health considerations and incorporated them into the safe operating procedures.



Training: OPPD has a training program related to operation, inspection, and maintenance of the SCR anhydrous ammonia system to ensure safe operation.



Mechanical Integrity: OPPD has written procedures for maintaining the integrity of the process equipment. OPPD has identified inspections and maintenance practices needed to comply with the standard. The maintenance program is in accordance with good engineering practices and in accordance with manufacturers' recommendations.



All of the elements of OPPD's Program 3 Prevention Program have been developed with the intent of preventing the accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

Omaha Public Power District's (OPPD) Nebraska City Station is a coal-fired electric generating facility. It is located 5 miles south of Nebraska City in Otoe County, Nebraska.  Nebraska City Station's Unit 2 uses anhydrous ammonia in the operation of its selective catalytic reduction (SCR) pollution prevention system. Anhydrous ammonia is the only Risk Management Program (RMP) listed chemical that is present at Nebraska City Station above the threshold quantity.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

OPPD is committed to employee and public safety and the protection of the environment. To demonstrate this commitment, OPPD has invested significant resources in preventing the release of anhydrous ammonia; as is evident in all elements of OPPD's prevention program.  As an example, OPPD requires all employees, contractors, vendors, and unescorted visitors to take general ammonia awareness training.



Overall safety at Nebraska City Station is governed not only by the ability to prevent accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia from occurring, but also by the ability to mitigate any accidental releases that may occur. OPPD has developed a robust emergency response program which includes having a trained Hazardous Material Response Team on-site and coordinating emergency response with the local emergency response agency. 



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

OPPD's Program 3 Prevention Program for the anhydrous ammonia system is a rigorous program which meets the requirements of both the RMP and the PSM regulations. 



OPPD updated and revalidated its Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) on 12/28/2012. The review examined the hazards associated with the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) process and the use of anhydrous ammonia. It also assessed the opportunities for equipment malfunction or human errors that could cause an accidental release. Safeguard

s used or needed to control the hazards or prevent equipment malfunction or human error were evaluated. The analysis also included the review of steps used or needed to detect or monitor releases. 



In addition to the PHA, OPPD's Program 3 Prevention Program incorporates all of the required elements, including:



Operating Procedures: OPPD has developed written operating procedures for the safe storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia at Nebraska City Station. The procedures specify steps for each operating phase of the process and operating limits (e.g., pressure in the tanks). OPPD has outlined appropriate safety and health considerations and incorporated them into the safe operating procedures.



Training: OPPD has a training program related to the operation, inspection, and maintenance of the SCR anhydrous ammonia system to ensure safe operation.



Mechanical Integrity: OPPD has written procedures for maintaining the integrity of the process equipment. OPPD has identified inspections and maintenance practices needed to comply with good engineering practices and in accordance with manufacturers' recommendations.



Five-Year Accident History:

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia at the time of this filing.



Emergency Response Program:

OPPD has developed a robust emergency response program and written Emergency Response Plan to minimize the effects of a release of anhydrous ammonia to employees, the public, and the environment. The emergency response program includes having a trained, on-site Hazardous Material Response Team available to respond to releases. OPPD also coordinates emergency response planning with the local emergency response agency.  



In the event of fire, explosion, or release of anhydrous ammonia; alarm systems are activated and emergency response is directed as initial evacuation occurs. Re-entry with personal protective equipment including respiratory protection and monitoring instrumentation is required if t

he ambient atmosphere ammonia levels exceed specified levels. Both emergency response and emergency medical procedures are documented and stressed during emergency response training on-site.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

OPPD is continually evaluating the hazards of operation of the anhydrous ammonia system.  During the 12/28/2012 update and revalidation of the Process Hazard Analysis, a list of recommendations was developed to improve safety. The PHA recommendations will be reviewed, promptly addressed (if applicable), and documented.
